Supporters of an independent Catalonia have been demonstrating almost daily, sometimes violently, since Spain‚Äôs supreme court jailed nine Catalan secessionist leaders for their roles in the region‚Äôs illegal independence referendum in 2017.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
But the independence movement doesn‚Äôt split only Catalonia and Spain. Secession divides Catalans down lines of age, class and language. More locals oppose than support independence, despite the loud campaigning of the region‚Äôs pro-separatist government.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
In Barcelona, the region‚Äôs capital, secession is pitting young against old, Catalan-speakers against Spanish-speakers, and hipsters against the proletariat. Support for independence is highest among people who are mostly young, educated and middle-class.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Ciutat Meridiana, a maze of 1960s tower blocks on the northern edge of Barcelona, is the city‚Äôs poorest neighborhood. It is also where pro-independence parties tend to perform the worst, winning just 17% of the vote in the last local elections.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
The hip central neighborhood of Gr√†cia, with its leafy squares and vegan restaurants, is a different story. The district is a bedrock of the pro-separatist movement, with starred Catalan flags draped over the balconies of almost every building.‚Å†‚†Ä

‚†Ä

‚†Ä

Eddie Murphy was 19 years old in 1980 when he exploded into the American consciousness on "Saturday Night Live," bringing urban sass, pop-culture insight and wicked wit to characters like Gumby, Mister Robinson and Buckwheat, while in the process reviving the flagging comedy franchise. As a comedian and an African-American, Murphy pushed boundaries, opened doors and made millions. Next year will mark Murphy‚Äôs 40th as an entertainer, and it‚Äôs shaping up to be a big one.‚†Ä
‚†Ä

‚Å†‚†Ä
In the coming year, the 58-year-old comedian and star of the new movie @dolemiteismyname will finish filming "Coming 2 America," host @nbcsnl, prepare for a reboot of "Beverly Hills Cop" and, most notably, stage a return to stand-up comedy.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"Everybody‚Äôs got this expectation. I don‚Äôt even know what‚Äôs going to come out. I‚Äôm curious to see what happens when I put it all together and get onstage. I hope to live up to everybody‚Äôs expectations. Whatever it is, it‚Äôs going to be me," Murphy says.‚†Ä

Everybody wants to have the highest credit score possible. While the average U.S. household credit-card balance is more than $8,000, most people have little idea how to help their credit‚Äîor what's really hurting it. ‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä

It can make it more likely to win approval for an apartment, and get deposits waived when setting up services like electricity and cable in a new home. It can even mean a better chance at nabbing a job offer.‚Å†‚†Ä

William and Theresa Reilly were biking on a leafy trail north of Detroit when their son, Billy, sent a text from his trip to Russia. The 28-year-old's foreign-language and computer skills led to part-time work in counterterrorism for the FBI, and the Reillys didn't know if the trip was somehow connected.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Despite plans to return home soon, Billy texted that he wasn't leaving Russia just yet. That was the last his parents heard from him.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†Over the course of four years, the Reillys would learn that no one in government wanted to take responsibility for their son's work or for his safety.‚Å†‚†Ä

Facebook and a host of small, upstart internet providers are trying to connect more customers to cheaper internet by providing wireless connections at comparable speeds to what traditional fiber can deliver, at a cheaper price than big cable companies are providing.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Facebook is working on a system where the fiber, airwaves and nodes create a mesh of wireless coverage that helps service providers avoid running physical fiber to every house they want to reach. When one signal in the mesh network that the nodes create gets blocked, the system automatically reroutes it to avoid service disruptions. ‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Combined, these internet providers control just a small slice of American households but aim to take more as consumers cut the cord and seek cheaper alternatives to traditional broadband providers. In some cases, the upstarts will compete with the faster 5G home broadband service that carriers like Verizon are racing to roll out.‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä

Welcome to the American Dream mall, home to the Western Hemisphere's biggest indoor ski hill, the biggest enclosed amusement park and a professional-size ice rink. ‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
Oh, and there's shopping, too. ‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
The most expensive U.S. mall ever built opened in New Jersey on Friday and will continue to open in phases stretching to 2021. Legoland Discovery Center and the Sea Life Aquarium will open in the spring; KidZania and an Angry Birds-themed 18-hole indoor golf course are in the works. ‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä

The nearly 90-acre site, built over swampland next to the Meadowlands Sports Complex, is the first in the U.S. to devote more space to entertainment, restaurants and theme-park rides than to traditional retail. After amenities such as a planned hotel and convention center are added, the total could reach $6 billion. The developer, Canada‚Äôs Triple Five Group, which also owns Mall of America in Minnesota, aims to draw 40 million visitors a year to the project. ‚Å†‚†Ä
‚Å†‚†Ä
But can lots of entertainment save the dying mall industry? Read more at the link in our bio.‚Å†‚†Ä

California‚Äôs rising gas price highlight a growing divide across the country: Even at a time of abundant global oil supplies, regional differences in taxes, environmental rules and access to energy infrastructure can translate into large seasonal swings in gas prices.

Drivers in California have reported paying up to $5 for a gallon of gas this month, compared with the state average of $3.63 this year and the U.S. average of $2.60, according to price tracker GasBuddy.

Prices have surged this fall in California and other West Coast states following outages at several refineries in the region. Analysts said the coast is generally vulnerable because of its limited pipelines and refineries that turn oil into fuel products such as gasoline. Higher gas taxes in some states aiming to fund local infrastructure projects and varying pricing strategies by energy companies also drive gaps.

In a quest to mount the largest ever exhibit of artwork by Leonardo da Vinci, the Louvre Museum in Paris has spent the past decade navigating high-stakes‚Äîand highly unpredictable‚Äînegotiations to borrow from collections around the world.‚Å†
‚Å†
To coincide with the 500th anniversary of the Renaissance master‚Äôs death, the @museelouvre‚Äôs efforts provide a rare glimpse into the secretive bargaining between museums over art loans. When curators want to mount an ambitious show, they rarely own all the art they want to display. Of the roughly 160 works on display in this show, the Louvre itself only owns 32. ‚Å†
‚Å†
The rest‚Äîcoming from museums in Italy, Russia and more, plus 12 pieces from collections across the U.S.‚Äîhad to be expertly negotiated for. ‚Å†
‚Å†

J.D. Salinger would have turned 100 this year. ‚†Ä
The @nypl exhibit, which opened Friday and runs through Jan. 19, features everything from his Royal typewriter and a volume of handwritten notes to his collection of pipes.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚ÄúIt was a huge struggle deciding to lift the veil in this way on his life,‚Äù said the author‚Äôs son, Matt Salinger. ‚ÄúBut if not on his 100th birthday, when?‚Äù ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
‚ÄúThe Catcher in the Rye‚Äù author stopped publishing in 1965, but he continued to write for more than six hours a day until his death in 2010, said his son, who has been transcribing his father‚Äôs jotted notes and typed words. The prospect of more fiction has tantalized Salinger scholars and fans for decades, but it will take another five to seven years before new work is published, his son noted.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
For the moment, he is revealing nothing more, saying he doesn‚Äôt yet know exactly what his father‚Äôs archive contains. ‚ÄúEven if I did, I wouldn‚Äôt say, because I really want people to come to this [exhibit] without any sort of pre-established assumptions or feelings or presumptions.‚Äù‚†Ä

‚ÄúI would consider leaving the state if this keeps going on.‚Äù Californians have come face-to-face with an uncomfortable new reality: Large swaths of the state‚Äîby itself the fifth-largest economy in the world, and home to the globe‚Äôs most technologically advanced companies‚Äîmay be subject to the sort of abrupt blackouts normally associated with underdeveloped countries.

Last week, the utility company PG&E cut the power to about 2 million people stretching from south of San Francisco almost to the Oregon border, explaining that high winds and dry brush made it too dangerous to run electricity through the company‚Äôs lines. 
California‚Äôs three big investor-owned utilities now have regulatory permission to cut off power to parts of their service territories during strong winds to reduce the risk of their electric lines causing wildfires, after at least 21 blazes linked to utility equipment killed more than 100 people and burned tens of thousands of homes in recent years. ‚ÄúWe are seeing the scale and scope of something that no state in the 21st century should experience,‚Äù California Gov. Gavin Newsom said last week, calling on PG&E Monday to issue refunds to consumers and small businesses.

Many across Northern California who lost power for up to several days last week complained of financial losses, with some businesses saying they totaled tens of thousands of dollars.

More Saudi women today are wearing clothes that could have landed them in trouble with the police a few years ago. They‚Äôre ditching the plain black version of the abaya‚Äîa loose, body-covering dress that all Saudi women wear in public over their clothing to comply with decency laws‚Äîin favor of conservative but creative alternatives: sporty jumpsuits, business-cut robes and even kimonos.

Some Saudi women say they sense cultural norms changing on the ground as 34-year-old Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman moves to open this conservative society to the outside world. Women are driving on Saudi streets, jogging by the seaside and working in jobs once reserved for men, such as the military and police.

Sarah Taibah, a 30-year-old actress living in Jeddah, said she began wearing long cardigans or kimonos as a substitute for an abaya about four years ago. ‚ÄúI feel like it has become more socially acceptable and people are opening up,‚Äù said Taibah, shown here.

Still, the wardrobe change has drawn grumbling from some conservative Saudis, including women, the vast majority of whom still wear traditional black abayas. Outside relatively cosmopolitan cities such as Jeddah or Riyadh, women could still face harassment for violating dress codes deeply rooted in Saudi traditions.

Erie, Pa., has lost more than 30% of its population since 1960. Nearly 27% of the Rust Belt city‚Äôs residents live below the federal poverty level, well above the 14.6% U.S. poverty rate.

Older industrial cities across the Northeast and Midwest are struggling to replace lost manufacturing jobs after decades of deindustrialization. Under a plan to rebuild Erie‚Äôs blighted downtown with $150 million in public and private funds, the city presents a new test of whether‚Äîand how‚Äîa town built on manufacturing can redefine itself.

Erie also wants to get local investors and expats to invest in the city, using the type of local connections that have helped companies like American Tinning & Galvanizing and its president Robin Scheppner, pictured here, survive. "A lot of people in Erie think we might have a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to turn it around," says Joe Schember, the city's mayor. "And if we miss it, we might not have another chance." ‚†Ä
In Florida, state Surgeon General Scott Rivkees declared a public-health emergency in August in response to a hepatitis A outbreak that is now among the largest in the U.S. The state has had more than 3,000 cases since 2018 and 40 deaths, he told a legislative committee last month. On a typical day, this content firm of about 30 workers churns out dozens of posts from more than 100 Instagram accounts with a total reach of around 300 million followers‚Äîmore than @beyonce and @kimkardashian combined.

Instagram has spawned a behind-the-scenes industry that brokers content and followers to sell sponsored posts. These meme factories are reshaping how Instagram content is made, following social media‚Äôs basic formula: More shareable content yields more followers, which makes more money.

But a flood of Instagram ads, some disguised, sour the experience for users, potentially making trouble for Instagram‚Äôs parent company, Facebook. Instagram is central to the Facebook empire. Yet the platform has grown so big, so fast and so commercial that it risks losing the stylish and intimate aesthetic that made it wildly popular.

Ethel Meyer, 69, is one of an estimated one million Americans who have Parkinson's disease, and has hand tremors from the disease, which has no cure.

That aligns with a recent study showing that Parkinson‚Äôs patients who did karate for one hour twice a week for 10 weeks performed better in several areas, including frequency of falls, quality of life and overall well-being. ‚ÄúAll exercise is a plus, but with karate and especially kata‚Äîthe drill sequence that is done on both sides of the body‚Äîwe are seeing the possibility of new neural pathways that help with balance and gait," said neurologist Jori Fleisher, the primary investigator of the study.

The study was small and limited, but the level of engagement among participants was encouraging. Other exercises such as tai chi, boxing and dancing have previously been found to alleviate some symptoms and improve physical mobility.

For Meyer, who also does cardio-spin and work with a personal trainer, karate gives her something she doesn‚Äôt get from the other activities. ‚ÄúI like the sense of achievement‚Ä¶the competitiveness with yourself,‚Äù she says, proudly pointing to her orange belt, the third-ranking up from beginner status. ‚ÄúThe important thing is to keep at it, to not let your Parkinson‚Äôs be an excuse,‚Äù says Meyer. ‚ÄúAnd to keep on exercising because it is the only thing you can control.‚Äù Read more at the link in our bio. üì∑: @tayloremrey for @wsjphotos

Those efforts haven't been enough, and the rising prices are threatening to mar the celebratory mood ahead of the 70th anniversary of Communist Chinese rule.

Without a viable vaccine for African swine fever‚Äîwhich is harmless to humans' health, but lethal for hogs‚Äîthe threat of another outbreak has discouraged farmers from expanding or restoring production. Luo Hengfeng rushed his hogs to market at discount, even though none had fallen ill, and out of a herd of hogs that once numbered more than 500, Luo now has just two. In the longer run, one of the government‚Äôs biggest hurdles will be persuading farmers like Luo to raise more pigs.

More than 40 years ago, director Francis Ford Coppola mortgaged his home to cover the budget for his Vietnam War epic ‚ÄúApocalypse Now.‚Äù "I own 'Apocalypse Now.' I own a lot of my own films. Whenever a hurricane, wildfire or tornado destroys homes, disaster investors arrive looking to profit.

Remember VisiCalc, the world's first spreadsheet? It was the first killer app, the spark for @apple's early success and a trigger for the broader PC boom that vaulted @microsoft to its central position in business computing. And within a few years, it was tech-industry roadkill.

The story of VisiCalc, a humble spreadsheet program that set the tech world ablaze 40 years ago, has reverberated through the industry and still influences the decisions of executives, engineers and investors. Its lessons include the power of simplicity and the difficulty of building a hypergrowth company in a hypergrowth industry.

The vista above Horseshoe Bend in Page, Arizona, has become one of the most popular national park destinations in America‚Äîthanks to Instagram.

Just a decade ago, fewer than 40,000 people would visit the attraction in a year, city officials say. But then came social media, leading an estimated two million people to converge on Horseshoe Bend annually, officials say.

The crowds have created a tourism boom in Page, where restaurants have hourlong waits for dinner many nights and new businesses have been formed, including sightseeing tours on an adjoining Navajo reservation.

The onslaught has been particularly challenging for Horseshoe Bend and other previously sleepy destinations, with crowds creating problems that range from traffic to trash to deaths.

Five people have fallen off the edge of Horseshoe Bend and died since 2017‚Äîthe first such fatalities since 2010, according to National Park Service statistics.

Anne Marie Vasconcelos, 42, is among the growing number of women in the U.S. pursuing single motherhood, thanks to economic independence fueled by increasing wages for women and employment in higher-paying occupations.

Combined with more widely available consumer credit for fertilization treatments, greater social acceptance and improved fertility benefits, the choice to pursue single motherhood has become easier. "I couldn't even say the words 'I'll never be a mom' without crying," said Vasconcelos, who underwent five artificial inseminations and two in vitro fertilization treatments, while having three miscarriages. Then, at 38, she gave birth to her first son. After another IVF treatment and two frozen embryo transfers, she gave birth to her second son about five months ago.

Vasconcelos‚Äôs insurance as a federal government employee wouldn‚Äôt cover most of the costs, so she took on credit-card debt, borrowed against her home and retirement fund, and depleted her savings. But she says she has no regrets.

In Tapachula, Mexico, near the Guatemalan border, a line of Central American migrants stretches down the street and around the corner from the local office of the federal refugee agency. Entire families, single mothers carrying children and young men who say they are fleeing threats from criminal gangs wait for hours in the hot sun to start or continue their asylum paperwork, a procedure far fewer people pursued during the early months of this year. Many arrive at night and sleep on the street to be among the first attended to. Most are Guatemalans, Hondurans and Salvadorans, but they also include Cubans, Venezuelans, Haitians and Africans.

Some say they want to stay in Mexico because getting into the U.S. is increasingly difficult. Others just want papers allowing them to move freely through Mexico on their way to the U.S. Many say they are seeking asylum in Mexico because they see it as protection from detention and deportation now that the Mexican government has stepped up enforcement.

From January through May, asylum requests in Mexico almost tripled from the same period a year ago to some 24,400. The upsurge in asylum requests comes amid a shortage of resources: the Tapachula office alone has nearly 13,000 unresolved asylum cases, and just 35 employees to process the applications.

Naomi Granger ditched her desk job after 12 years as a public accountant to launch a freelance accounting practice that helps marijuana startups. Over the past several years, 33 U.S. states and Washington, D.C., have adopted laws that allow adults to smoke pot for recreation or to treat medical conditions, fueling the rise of thousands of new businesses like Granger's.

She works out of her home in Las Vegas and says her pay can range from $5,000 to $30,000 a month, but that's not her favorite part of the job. This year Ben Congleton took three months of paternity leave from the 30-person company he founded to care for his newborn daughter. So did his cofounder ‚Äî at the exact same time. Their employees found that life at work didn't go off the rails with the bosses gone. "When employees see the CEO and COO use our parental-leave policy and have faith that it's going to work, they think, 'Hey, I can do the same thing if I need to.' " said Mandy Smith, the company's director of people operations.

Few men take more than a few days' parental leave without an explicit endorsement of their right to it, according to the 11-nation study. Many face social stigma and career damage if they do.

In the U.S., only 15% of civilian workers have access to paid family leave, skewed toward high-paid workers in white-collar jobs at companies with 500 or more employees, according to an annual federal survey.

More new fathers are now getting a taste of what working mothers have faced for decades. "A lot of it is societal pressure around what it means to be a mom," Congleton said, adding that women sometimes chide other mothers, asking how they can go back to work when they have two small children at home. "No one ever says that to a dad." Read more at the link in our bio. üì∑: @angeladecenzo for @wsjphotos

Five days after the Easter morning bombings in Sri Lanka claimed by Islamic State, which killed more than 250 people at churches and high-end hotels, armed troops and police closed in on a safe house linked to the plotters of the coordinated attack. Gunfire erupted from inside. Three explosions rocked the home.

Inside and around the house, authorities found at least 15 bodies, including those of the suicide bombers' families, who police believe were a part of the plan‚Äîa father, brothers and the wives of the plotters.

Unlike previous international terrorist threats such as al Qaeda, which generally operated with tight groups of men directed by insulated, faraway leaders, security experts point to a hallmark of Islamic State‚Äôs terror operations: families.

Typical counterterror tactics, such as infiltrating radical mosque networks and jihadist chat groups, are less effective when plots are formed over the dinner table.

Now, at 28 years old, he owes about $39,000 in student loans, while his mother owes about $62,000 in parent loans, a balance that is growing because she can't afford the full monthly payment.

Long a path to financial security, historically black colleges and universities are now producing graduates who struggle with disproportionately high debt.

Students of HBCUs are leaving school with higher loans than their peers at other colleges, a Wall Street Journal analysis of @usedgov data found, and they are less likely to repay those loans than they were a decade ago.

In fact, the majority of HBCU grads haven't paid down even $1 of their original loan balance in the first few years out of school.

In the 1950s, rocket scientists believed our move into space seemed inevitable. But things turned out differently‚Äîso what went wrong?

According to Wernher von Braun, the rocket scientist from Nazi Germany who became a leader of the U.S. space program, humankind was due to take up residence beyond Earth five decades ago. "Within the next 10 or 15 years, the Earth can have a new companion in the skies, a manmade satellite which will be man's first foothold in space," von Braun wrote in "Crossing the Last Frontier," part of a celebrated Collier's magazine series on space travel that began in 1952.

In von Braun‚Äôs vision, shiny, reusable space shuttles would shoot into orbit almost daily. That first wave of brave souls would piece together a huge wheel-shaped space station, which would serve as a hub for manned missions to the moon and, eventually, Mars.

None of the technology in von Braun's future was farfetched, but none of it has so far come to pass as he predicted. Now, after more than half a century of ups and downs, life in space is once again in our sights, though we‚Äôre still looking for a reason to go beyond Earth in a lasting and meaningful way.

When Sabrina Jones was diagnosed with aggressive breast cancer, she expected to have invasive surgery to remove the tumor‚Äîand her entire breast. "My first instinct was 'get it out, get the cancer out,'" Ms. Jones said.

But after undergoing chemotherapy at @MDAndersonCancerCenter in Houston, she was informed that the cancerous tumor was completely gone. Her surgeon asked her to participate in an experiment in which she avoided surgery altogether. "I had to wrap my brain around the fact the cancer was gone and there was nothing left" to remove, she said. "It is scary because it was not the traditional protocol." Henry Kuerer, the MD Anderson surgeon leading the trial, says the non-surgery course is open only to women with certain types of breast cancer that respond completely to drug treatment. He hopes his trial will show it is safe to spare women an operation. "I would be ecstatic if all of us [surgeons] would be put out of business," he says.

Michelle Lowry was a healthy baby until a small lump appeared on her neck, caused by a fusing of genes found in about 1% of solid tumors that can cause cancer in virtually any tissue type in the body. Within weeks it had swelled into a life-threatening tumor obstructing her breathing.

Her doctors at Children's Hospital Los Angeles got her enrolled in a clinical trial to take an experimental drug, shrinking the tumor within days. Within weeks, it wasn't even visible.

New cancer drugs like the one Michelle took, which target tumors based on their genetic characteristics, are aiming to be an alternative to chemotherapy and radiation. "While we may not be able to cure cancer, we may be able to control it much like we do with high blood pressure or diabetes," said Leo Mascarenhas, deputy director of the Children's Center for Cancer and Blood Diseases at @childrensla and one of Michelle's doctors.

The horror of the shooting in Parkland, Florida, that occurred one year ago today crosses Ina Berlingeri-Vincenty's mind every morning when she drops her son Nico off at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.

Before he gets out of the car, she says, "I make sure I say, 'I love you.'" The gunman behind the rampage that left 17 people dead spared Nico's classroom, but not the one next door. Nico's older sister, Amanda, was studying Holocaust history in that classroom and saw two of her friends die beside her. 
In the shooting's aftermath, Amanda would wake up crying and some days couldn't bring herself to enter the school. In any enclosed space, she plotted escape routes. Her parents eventually pulled her out of school to complete her senior year online.

The Parkland community has grieved and erected memorials. Some families who lost loved ones, and students who survived, have channeled their anguish into activism. Many have undergone counseling and recaptured a semblance of normalcy.

But pain and anger still pour forth regularly‚Äîespecially as the political fallout from the shooting continues. A litany of errors in law enforcement's handling of the shooting was revealed in January. About a week later, Gov. Ron DeSantis suspended Broward County Sheriff Scott Israel, who was in charge of the police response. Mr. Israel is challenging the move.

Transcranial alternating-current stimulation may sound like something out of science fiction, but for some doctors it may be a key to treating lower-back pain.

Innovative ways to measure, understand and treat pain are allowing doctors to ease patients' suffering without relying on dangerous drugs‚Äîand the need has never been more urgent. 
More than 50 million adults in the U.S. are living with chronic pain at an estimated annual cost of $560 billion in medical care, lost productivity and disability programs, data show. Lower-back pain is among the most common of complaints.

By delivering weak alternating currents of electricity through electrodes on the scalp, health officials showed they could enhance naturally occurring brain rhythms and significantly decrease symptoms of lower-back pain in just one session.

Preliminary data show a jump in Florida home purchases by buyers from heavily taxed states, with public officials  blaming the exodus on the 2017 law capping a deduction for state and local taxes at $10,000. 
Miami is experiencing more activity than usual from buyers living in states like New York, New Jersey and Illinois. People are drawn to the city by mild weather‚Äîas always‚Äîand by deals on condos and lower taxes. They are stepping in after foreign buyers, who helped lift Miami's condo market out of a tailspin following the financial crisis, have pulled back. "I've been starting to see New Yorkers as Florida's new foreign buyer," said real estate appraiser Jonathan Miller. Margaret Johnson learned a painful lesson over the past four years: It is hard for murder victims in her Brooklyn neighborhood to get justice.

Her 24-year-old son, Shane Johnson, was fatally shot on Sept. 11, 2014, in the borough's Canarsie section. His killing remains unsolved. "Once it started getting cold," she said, "I realized he had become a statistic." New York is in the middle of a historic drop in homicides, but a Wall Street Journal analysis of @nypd data shows that killings in certain pockets of the city are stubbornly difficult to solve.

Half of the unsolved homicides committed from 2013 through 2017 happened in 11 of the city's 77 police precincts, where only a third of the homicides occurred. Those precincts have majority-minority populations and tend to have higher poverty rates. 
Murders of black men in south Brooklyn, including Canarsie, were solved half of the time, while all but one of the nondomestic cases involving white men were solved.

Six-year-old Avalynn Wallace contracted an aggressive form of leukemia two years ago. Following many chemotherapy rounds, she kept relapsing and developed infections, eventually undergoing a stem-cell transplant.

Now, a new law requiring pharmaceuticals companies to test cancer drugs on children as well as adults is raising hopes of more therapies.

This summer, a pediatric oncologist at Stanford will launch a clinical trial of an adult leukemia drug made by Roche on children whose leukemia has relapsed. The trial may help some of his patients, including Avalynn. "I don't think there are many options for us," said her mother, Nicole Wallace. "I think that it is important for drug companies to offer trials for drugs that could cure these horrific diseases children go through." Pharmaceuticals companies are already ramping up for the legislation, which goes into effect in 2020, with some planning children's drug trials this year.

El Salvador, Honduras and Guatemala annually register the deaths of thousands of young men who shoot, stab, bludgeon and asphyxiate each other, often in gang-related violence. Now, Central America's so-called Northern Triangle is turning deadly for women, too.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
El Salvador, a country of 6 million, has seen homicides of women more than double since 2013, to 469 last year. The homicide rate per 100,000 women, at 13.5, is more than six times that of the U.S., with Honduras and Guatemala close behind. What amounts to a public health crisis has women of all ages living in fear, according to researchers and interviews with dozens of women in El Salvador. Gang violence has turbocharged the problem, but doesn't explain all of it.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"Women are looked down upon as they grow up, making them second-class citizens," said Silvia Ju√°rez, a lawyer with the Organization of Salvadoran Women for Peace, which catalogs violence against women. "Homicides will only be brought under control when we teach society that women‚Äôs lives are worth more."‚†Ä

Get a job. Ex-prisoners hear that message all the time, from parole officers, from family members and even from other former inmates.‚†Ä

Each of the men faced challenges, but all three were eventually hired.‚†Ä

Back in the '70s, Greenville, S.C., had become a rundown old mill town. Dozens of companies that once operated in the so-called Textile Capital of the World closed down when manufacturing shifted overseas, leading to blight and high unemployment. In the '80s, other types of manufacturing started to emerge, and today the vibrant arts scene is revitalizing the Southern city of 68,000, attracting other artists, young professionals and families wanting a fun, affordable place to live.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The campaign to make Greenville into a cool city‚Äîthe next Portland, Ore.‚Äîbegan in 2012 and is centered around the catchphrase "Yeah, that," as in yes, the Greenville in South Carolina as opposed to some 36 other towns named Greenville across the United States. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
What makes the city different is that many of the newly arrived artists are already established‚Äînot stereotypically young and starving. Because of that, the newcomers are buying high-end homes and building studios. Average home prices have risen in the city over 20% in the past three years, and the number of homes priced $1 million and over has almost tripled during that time.‚†Ä

George Herbert Walker Bush, America's 41st president and the father of its 43rd, died on Friday at age 94.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Mr. Bush was the last American president to serve in World War II, a fight that helped shape his life and the lives of many in his generation. He went on to build a sterling resume‚Äîbusinessman, member of Congress, envoy to the United Nations and China, head of the Central Intelligence Agency‚Äîbefore becoming Republican Ronald Reagan's vice president in 1980 and then succeeding him in the White House in the election in 1988.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
As president, he led the U.S. to a swift and decisive victory in the first Persian Gulf War and presided over the peaceful dissolution of the Soviet Union and unification of Germany, before a painful recession cost him a second term as president.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
When his wife of more than 70 years, Barbara Bush, died at the age of 92 earlier this year, the former president's office described him as heartbroken but strong and stoic. Of her passing, Mr. Bush said: "We have faith she is in heaven, and we know life will go on‚Äîas she would have it. So cross the Bushes off your worry list."‚†Ä

California's Mountain Pass mine‚Äîthe only current U.S. source of "rare earth" minerals critical to high-tech applications, including military equipment‚Äîis between a rock and a hard place.‚†Ä

Six months after a hedge fund became majority owner of the mine and brought it out of bankruptcy, President Trump announced an executive order that would seem like its golden ticket: The U.S. should stop buying key minerals overseas, and instead promote domestic supplies, as a matter of national security.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
But as is often the case with global trade, the situation is complicated. The mine's owner first ships its ore to China, home to most of the processors, refiners and parts-makers that turn rare earths into products for customers all over the world, including the U.S.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
That exposed it to problems when Washington announced tariffs of up to 25% on Chinese imports entering the U.S. China retaliated with its own tariffs on U.S. goods‚Äîincluding ore from Mountain Pass.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Now, a mine that is ready to produce minerals it sees as crucial to national security is caught up in the government's other goal of punishing China for what it sees as unfair trading practices. Read more at the link in our bio. ‚†Ä

Two years ago, Christa Bottomley‚Äôs healthy 5-year-old son Sebastian caught a viral cold like the rest of the family. Everyone else recovered, but in his case the virus triggered a polio-like neurological condition called acute flaccid myelitis, or AFM.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Every two years since 2014 @CDCgov has documented a spike in AFM, almost always in children. The CDC is investigating 219 reports of patients with AFM so far this year, with 80 cases in 25 states confirmed, up from 33 the year before.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Many doctors speculate AFM is largely fueled by a common virus called the enterovirus, which for most people causes nothing more than a routine upper-respiratory infection. But the CDC believes there could be other culprits.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
After a lengthy series of hospital stays, Sebastian has since had some mobility restored through surgeries and rehabilitation. He can walk with a walker and leg braces, though he still predominantly uses a wheelchair outside of the house.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Families like the Bottomleys are trying to provide hope to others hit with the disease and to push for more awareness in the medical community.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"I wish people had listened in 2016 when we said this is coming," Ms. Bottomley says. "Nobody wanted to listen. I think it will be the same thing in 2020, and hopefully we will have their attention then."‚†Ä

---‚†Ä

1) A portrait of Sternochetus mangiferae, a mango seed weevil. The image was taken by Pia Scanlon of the Government of Western Australia's Department of Primary Industries and Regional Development.

4) Crystals of amino acids, magnified four times in an image taken by Justin Zoll, are the building blocks of proteins.‚†Ä

A glut of timber has piled up in the Southeast. There are far more ready-to-cut trees than the region‚Äôs mills can saw or pulp. The surplus has crushed timber prices in Mississippi, Alabama and several other states.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
How did this happen? At the depths of the 1980s farm crisis, the Reagan administration offered farmers annual payments for each acre they planted with trees or grasses through the Conservation Reserve Program. By 1994, more than 2.2 million acres of farmland in the South had been converted to pine plantation. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Timber, meanwhile, gained popularity as an investment idea. People reasoned that trees would grow, and thus gain value, no matter what the stock market did.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"We figured we‚Äôd plant trees and come back and harvest it in 30 years and in the meantime go into town to make a living doing something else," says Clayton George, who planted loblolly pine on his Mississippi farmland in the 1980s, seen above.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Some timber harvests are now barely worth the effort after the expense of logging, hauling, taxes and replanting. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Timber has also been a big loser for some financial investors, among them the country‚Äôs largest pension fund. @CalPERS spent more than $2 billion on Southern timberland, and harvested trees at depressed prices to pay interest on money borrowed to buy. Calpers sold much of its land this summer at a loss. ‚†Ä

Storms are getting deadlier and causing more damage as more Americans live on the coasts. Since 1980, the U.S. has had 40 hurricanes identified as billion-dollar disasters, using 2018 inflation-adjusted dollars, with a cumulative damage estimate of $862 billion, according to @NOAA's U.S. Billion-Dollar Weather and Climate Disasters analysis. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Hurricanes Harvey, Maria and Irma in 2017 combined to cost $268 billion, 31% of the damage since 1980, making it the most expensive year in 38 seasons. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Relatively weak storms are among the costliest, as wind strength isn‚Äôt the only factor that determines how damaging a storm will be. Florence made landfall in the Carolinas over the summer as a Category 1 hurricane, but the devastating effect of Florence, like Harvey in 2017, was primarily related to flooding.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Another important factor contributing to increasing damage is the slowing speed of North Atlantic hurricanes as they cross over land. These weather systems have slowed by 17% from 1949 to 2016, says Jim Kossin, atmospheric scientist at NOAA. All things being equal, if you slow a storm‚Äôs forward speed by 17%, you will increase the rain in the area by 17%, resulting in substantially more freshwater flooding, he says.‚†Ä

Russia's third-class communal railroad cars, known as platzkarts, have for decades melded together people and customs from across the nation's 11 time zones for journeys that can last seven days aboard train carriages with 54 bunks crammed into about 600 square feet.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Now the platzkart's future is threatened by President Putin's drive to modernize the country's outdated infrastructure and stimulate an economy struggling under the weight of Western sanctions.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Starting next year, state-owned OAO Russian Railways will introduce transitional carriages boasting showers, vending machines and USB sockets. Then, in 2025, the raucous platzkarts originally manufactured in the former East Germany are expected to be replaced by sleek carriages with capsule-like berths.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Despite a boom in air travel, trains remain the dominant method of long-distance transport in Russia, which boasts a rail system with 54,000 miles of functioning track. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
One in four long-distance travelers within Russia rides in a platzkart, and some passengers worry the upgrade will bring an end to the kind of chance interaction that is unavoidable in these carriages, one which came to symbolize the egalitarian spirit of the Soviet Union. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"Time passes quicker in these wagons, between the conversations and anecdotes," said Andrey Kuznetsov, who works in the fishing industry and who was on a five-day journey from his home in Chelyabinsk to Russia's Far East. "You meet the whole country here."‚†Ä

A fiery, tearful Brett Kavanaugh defended his nomination to the Supreme Court and his personal reputation against allegations of sexual assault in an extraordinary Senate Judiciary Committee hearing Thursday, shortly after his accuser, Christine Blasey Ford, said she was 100% certain he had assaulted her decades earlier. "This confirmation process has become a national disgrace," Judge Kavanaugh told the committee in his opening statement, chastising the senators, his voice raised. 
Less than an hour earlier, Dr. Ford, a California college professor, had outlined in emotional detail her memories of an alleged incident that has become the center of the partisan fight over Judge Kavanaugh‚Äôs confirmation. 
Her voice halting at times, Dr. Ford told lawmakers she had been "haunted by memories" since the alleged attack at a house party in the summer of 1982, which she said had left her struggling academically and coping with panic and anxiety for decades after.

Instagram CEO Kevin Systrom made headlines last night after he announced that he is resigning and leaving the company in the coming weeks, along with co-founder Mike Krieger.‚†Ä
‚†Ä

‚†Ä
It‚Äôs now impossible to separate Instagram‚Äôs success from Facebook‚Äôs backing. In @WSJmag's October issue cover profile online now, Systrom talks about the road that led to the pivotal decision to sell, his personal life, and how he explains Instagram's success.‚†Ä

Just 4 years old, Caspian Soto uses a cane and headlamp to help him see when he walks. He can't see in dark places like aquariums or movie theaters. He's never seen the stars.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Caspian was born with a rare, inherited eye disorder called Leber congenital amaurosis, which results in the progressive deterioration of the retina. He could lose all vision by the time he‚Äôs a teenager.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
This month Caspian became among the first patients in the U.S. to receive a new gene-therapy treatment called Luxturna, which his doctors at @ohsunews believe will improve his vision and prevent deterioration. At $850,000, it's among one of the most expensive treatments on the market, and getting insurance plans to approve the therapy is time-consuming. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"There was a lot of back and forth with things getting approved, denied and then approved," says Krista Soto, Caspian‚Äôs mom. She started the work of getting her husband‚Äôs health insurance to pay for the treatment in January. At OHSU they've set up a five-person team to work on getting insurance to approve the therapy. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Pharmaceutical companies are working on similar therapies for other vision disorders caused by single genes, raising questions about how the health system will absorb such treatments as they become more common.‚†Ä

Artist Njideka Akunyili Crosby had been selling her works for $3,000 apiece just a few years ago. By early 2017, one of her paintings sold at Christie's in London for $3 million, more than six times its estimate.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"My friends tell me I should just be happy my works are selling, and I am," said the artist, whose jet-propelled rise to the top of the contemporary art world is a far cry from the small town in eastern Nigeria where she grew up.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Collectors in the booming world of contemporary art are voracious for fresh stars, thronging around the handful of "it" artists who emerge in any given season. That drives prices sky high, but it also often sets them up for a precipitous crash.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"A lot of people in the art business get young artists and just wreck them‚Äîthey ruin them," says Randall Exon, a studio art professor at Swarthmore College who taught Ms. Akunyili Crosby.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Now, the marketplace is her tightrope. "It‚Äôs scary how vulnerable I still feel," she says. ‚†Ä

A murder crisis has taken hold across much of Latin America and the Caribbean, which today is the world's most violent region. Every day, more than 400 people are murdered there, a yearly tally of about 145,000 dead.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
With just 8% of the world's population, Latin America  accounts for roughly a third of global homicides. Nearly one in every four murders world-wide now takes place in just four countries: Brazil, Venezuela, Mexico and Colombia. Last year, Brazil and Mexico each saw a record number of murder victims, at 63,808 and 32,174, respectively. In El Salvador, the murder rate of 83 per 100,000 people in 2016‚Äîthe world's highest‚Äîwas nearly 17 times that of the U.S.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
At the morgue in Acapulco‚Äîa city where more people were violently killed last year than in Italy, Spain, Switzerland, Portugal and the Netherlands combined‚Äîbodies pile up faster than workers can process them.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"We never catch up," says a top forensic official. "While we're trying to clear the first set of bodies, another set of bodies arrives."‚†Ä

In the summer of 1969, California native Cherrill Meyer traveled to Wolfsburg, West Germany, to buy her Volkswagen Beetle, after her father learned she could shave $700 off the $1,700 price tag by picking it up directly from the factory.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
With the cash she saved, Cherrill and her childhood friend Pam Burk traveled for three months through Germany, Holland, Austria, France and Switzerland. The friends, both 20 at the time, named the '69 Beetle "Baby Cham" after a Champagne cocktail they had along the way. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
All through the summer, they listened to news on Armed Forces Radio. "So much happened," Ms. Cherrill says. "The Manson murders, Chappaquiddick, Woodstock. We were in Bern, Switzerland, when Neil Armstrong walked on the moon." Sometimes other American tourists would ask them, "Where are your parents?!" ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Ms. Cherrill, now 69 and a retired corporate-communications director living in Los Angeles, shipped the car from Germany to California and has kept it for the last 49 years (and 123,000 miles). ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"It has been in the parking lot at every job I have ever had," says Ms. Cherrill, who reunited with her friend in Baby Sham for this photoshoot. "When I drive it, baby boomers stop to listen to the engine, because it brings back so many memories for people of my generation."‚†Ä

Glenner Town Square, a new adult day-care center for dementia patients in Chula Vista, Calif., is like entering a time warp.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The storefronts that surround an indoor park there represent the time period from 1953 to 1961, when most of the patients were in the prime of their life.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The center opened in August and is believed to be the country's first memory-care facility built entirely around the idea of reminiscence therapy, which uses prompts from a person's past to elicit memories and encourage conversation and engagement.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Research on reminiscence therapy is mixed, although there is some evidence it can improve quality of life, cognition, communication and mood.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"You want to have an environment that fits the kind of memories that people have," says Dorthe Berntsen, a psychology professor and head of the Center on Autobiographical Memory Research at Aarhus University in Denmark. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"It doesn't cure dementia, of course, but it does provide a context where these people have a better connection to their past and to their sense of identity."‚†Ä

Romania is fighting a deadly measles outbreak that has seen more than 15,000 people infected and claimed 59 lives since 2016. That's thrown a spotlight on plummeting vaccination rates in the poor country, which has emerged as the leading edge of an escalating antivaccine trend plaguing Europe in recent years.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Mistrust of authorities, a vocal antivaccine movement, poverty, irregular supply of vaccines and obstacles to delivering them to marginalized communities has exacerbated disease risks.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
More than 41,000 people were infected with measles in the first half of this year in the wider European region, compared with roughly 24,000 for all of 2017, according to the World Health Organization. By contrast, the U.S. saw about 100 cases during the same period this year.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
In Poland, an antivaccination movement recently gathered enough signatures to force a parliamentary debate on a proposal to make vaccines voluntary. In August, Italy's Senate voted to suspend for a year a requirement that parents provide proof of vaccinations to enroll their children in preschools.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Meanwhile, in Ukraine, vaccination rates plummeted to 42% in 2016 from 97% in 2007. Ukraine has had nearly 30,000 cases of measles this year, including 13 deaths.‚†Ä

MIT research scientist Josh Siegel was just old enough to get his learner's permit at 14 when he found a 1955 Chevrolet 210 for sale online. Living in suburban Detroit at the time, he bought the car for $3,000 with earnings from his job at a summer camp job teaching kids to build model cars. ‚†Ä

‚†Ä
The Catholic Church has been on the front lines. Clergy have been assaulted and at least 10 churches have been attacked, shot at, looted or defiled during the last three months. During a  speech last week, Mr. Ortega said the bishops were allied with opponents seeking a violent coup.‚†Ä

For the last two years, Louisville, Ky., entrepreneur Jim Patterson's 1937 Cadillac has been in a constant state of restoration. It now is in the final weeks of preparation for the Pebble Beach Concours d‚ÄôElegance, the Kentucky Derby of car shows, where it will debut next month. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
This one-of-a-kind Cadillac's story begins in Switzerland, where in the mid-1930s, a man from Lausanne wanted to buy the biggest, baddest car that could exist in that society, Mr. Patterson said. ‚†Ä
Car manufacturers in those days did not always make bodies for their cars, but rather supplied the frame and motor, leaving the buyer to order a custom body. In this case, the original owner had a Swiss firm build the body. The end result was a 22-foot-long car with an equally impressive 16-cylinder engine. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The vehicle was essentially left to rot for years following World War II, and Mr. Patterson believes it was imported to the U.S. in the late 1960s and underwent some restoration. It was kept in the @blackhawkmuseum in Danville, Calif., until it came up for sale three years ago. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
He immediately began a full restoration after buying it, and a tremendous amount of research has gone into finding out what the original looked like. Mr. Patterson found a former worker for General Motors who remembered seeing the car when it was first brought to the U.S. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Privately, he has shown the Cadillac to friends in the car business. Their first reaction is always, "Wow, what is it? A Packard? A Duesenberg?" he said. It isn't. It's a Cadillac with a Swiss body.‚†Ä

Oil prices are back up to their highest levels in more than three years, and U.S. production has topped record levels. But as of May, nationwide oil and gas employment had fallen 21% since 2014.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
For decades, high-school graduates could jump into a job on a drilling rig with few technical skills and expect a well-paid career. The allure of the often dangerous life of a roughneck attracted generations of workers from Oklahoma to Wyoming, but now technology is upending the energy business. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The energy sector had been shielded from pressure to innovate by high oil prices. When prices fell 75% over 20 months beginning in 2014, oil and gas companies were finally forced to modernize to squeeze out profits. Many found they could use new technologies to do the work better and cheaper‚Äîwith fewer people. They have invested billions of dollars on what the industry dubs "digital oil fields," embracing artificial intelligence, automation and other technologies.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
In Wamsutter, Wyo., BP built a 47,000-square-foot command hub a decade ago meant to house 300 workers monitoring about 2,000 wells. The company's subsequent embrace of technology, such as drones equipped with infrared imaging to determine which oil tanks are full, has allowed it to reduce its head count there to about 100. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
BP built the town's park, health clinic and day-care center. The cafeteria in the command hub used to be the best dining option. It is now closed, and funding has dried up for other civic projects, residents said.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"It was going to be the greatest thing on earth," said Bobbie Amos, who works in the town library. "Everything was going to run in Wamsutter, but now here we are."‚†Ä

The Philippines has been riveted by a clash between popular President Rodrigo Duterte and the powerful Roman Catholic Church, which has sought to maintain its traditional moral authority while facing a barrage of criticism from the strongman leader.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The church has become one of the fiercest critics of the president's war on drugs in the overwhelmingly Catholic country, condemning thousands of killings and calling for restraint. That opposition has angered Mr. Duterte, who recently called God "stupid" for the concept of original sin and said he would resign if anyone could prove that God exists.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Some church leaders have offered sanctuary to drug suspects and witnesses to police shootings who are fearful for their lives. Many priests have converted church buildings into hiding places, reviving an ancient church concept that leverages secular authorities' reverence for holy places. Church officials estimate that hundreds of people are living under sanctuary. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Police say that more than 4,100 people have been killed, nearly all while resisting arrest, as part of official operations in the drug war. Various rights groups estimate the real toll at well over 10,000, including targeted executions by unknown killers or vigilantes.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Church leaders say they have a moral obligation to intervene. "If there was no church, there would be more killings," said the Rev. Gilbert Billbena, who protected suspected drug offenders for more than a year in a Manila neighborhood with a particularly high death toll in the drug war. "We believe that life is very sacred."‚†Ä

India boasts the world's largest dairy herd‚Äîsome 300 million buffalo and cows that produce 165 million metric tons of milk annually.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
But between cow and consumer, milk quality has suffered. Middlemen often sneak water, sugar or powdered milk into raw milk, adding volume and lowering the quality. That's why almost all Indians boil their milk‚Äîwhich is where Srikumar Misra saw an opening.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The former executive with one of India's largest conglomerates, and his wife, Rashima, a marketing executive who became a partner in the business, believed India's emerging middle class would spend more on a high-quality, healthy product.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Armed with social media, smartphone apps and big-data analytics, their dairy business Milk Mantra is among hundreds of start-up companies leveraging the arrival of the internet in rural areas in India.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The company pays farmers more for milk than informal collectors, while recording the quantity and the quality of the milk after it is tested for milk fat levels and contaminants at village collection points.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"There was a huge problem with food products that people could trust," Mr. Misra said. "The opportunity was addressing this trust deficit."‚†Ä

Family members pray before a shrine at the cave in Thailand where 12 youth soccer players and their coach remain trapped‚Äîas rescue workers raced the elements Thursday to advance two plans to pull them from the flooded cave system before monsoon rains start up again.‚†Ä

Thai Navy SEALs and an international crew of divers went into the cave in shifts to clear obstructions, bring in air tanks and medical supplies, and widen narrow passages before torrential rains resume as soon as Friday.‚†Ä

If they make enough progress, rescuers may decide on the dangerous course of guiding out some or all of the boys and their coach, who have been trapped in the cave since a flash flood cut them off from the entrance more than 12 days ago. Many of the passages are winding, narrow and still submerged, and none of the boys have dived before.‚†Ä

If the team doesn't make it out before the weather worsens, rescue experts have warned they might be stuck until the monsoon season ends, often in October or November.‚†Ä

When the Trump administration blacklisted Russia's biggest aluminum producer, United Co. Rusal, in April, it was among a blast of measures aimed at the country's elite. But the sanctions are already weighing on the residents of Sayanogorsk, a Siberian factory town more than 2,000 miles east of Moscow, where Rusal and its smelter  anchor the local economy.‚†Ä

The smelter is still running, employing more than 6,000 of Sayanogorsk's 45,000 residents. But Rusal has frozen its $24 million budget for community spending in company towns, including Sayanogorsk's $3 million share, according to a Rusal employee.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
That means plans for upgrades to the Rusal-built hospital are on hold. The company has also put off consideration of an expansion of the town's cultural centers and the renovation of a memorial wall in the town center.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"It was the first thing we had to look for to freeze," the employee said. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Hanging over the town is an October deadline set by the Trump administration for Russian billionaire Oleg Deripaska to sell down his majority stake in the holding company that owns 48% of Rusal and give up his seat on its board, which he has already done. Mr. Deripaska is one of the Russian businessmen targeted by U.S. sanctions because of perceived closeness to President Vladimir Putin.‚†Ä

"The life of the city depends on that factory," said Nina Chvaniva, one of the city's deputy mayors. "Otherwise there is no Sayanogorsk."‚†Ä

The U.S. Farm Belt helped deliver Donald Trump to the White House, drawn to his promises to revive rural America and deregulate industry. Now, the president's global trade offensive is threatening the livelihoods of many farmers.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Mounting trade disputes, spurred by U.S. threats to withdraw from Nafta and tariffs on billions of dollars' worth of goods from key trading partners, have cut U.S. agricultural exports and sent commodity prices tumbling.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Many American farmers, who depend on shipments overseas for one-fifth of the goods they produce, say they are anxious, especially because they are already expecting bumper harvests or grappling with a dairy glut.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"We live and die by trade," said Arkansas farmer Rusty Smith, who joined dozens of other farmers in Grand Rapids, Mich., last week to discuss trade and agricultural commodities.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Since April, duties the U.S. has levied on goods from China, Mexico, Canada and the European Union have sparked retaliatory tariffs and trade threats, targeting American farm goods from pork to cheese to apples.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The planned tariffs on products like soybeans, for which China is the U.S.'s top customer, come as farmers nationwide have boosted plantings of the crop.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
For Mr. Smith, who grows corn and soybeans on 1,500 acres in Cotton Plant, Ark., a 16% decline in soybean prices alone translates into a nearly $100 per-acre drop in the value of his crop. "That's $100,000 that has disappeared into thin air," he said. "We were already in the red, and now it's even worse."‚†Ä

First built in 1948, Deux Chevaux means "two horses," referring to a horsepower taxation classification. In Europe, the car is an icon. Millions were manufactured there over 42 years, but it is a rare sight in the U.S.‚†Ä

Ms. DeGuenther has brought her 2CV to car shows in Florida, Kentucky, North Carolina, New Jersey and New York. The morning of a show, she picks up fresh baguettes from a grocery store so her car smells like a French bakery, then hands them out to new friends.‚†Ä

Anthony M. Kennedy, one of the Supreme Court's most consequential modern-day justices and author of landmark rulings on gay rights, the death penalty and campaign finance, has announced his retirement, handing President Donald Trump a historic opportunity to reshape the court.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Justice Kennedy, a maverick conservative, told his colleagues of his decision after they stepped off the bench Wednesday for the final time in the court's current term. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
He spent much of his 30-year tenure at the ideological center of a deeply divided court, with his judicial leanings often leaving him in play for both sides.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
A native of Sacramento, Calif., Justice Kennedy was confirmed by the Senate in a 97-0 vote and joined the court in 1988 after his nomination by President Ronald Reagan. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The 81-year-old's decision to step down marks a seismic event in the nation's capital, one certain to create an impassioned political battle over the high court.‚†Ä

Experts have warned for years that robots will replace humans in restaurants. Instead, a twist on that prediction is unfolding. Amid the lowest unemployment in years, fast-food joints are turning to machines‚Äînot to get rid of workers, but because they can't find enough of them.‚†Ä

The chain plans to install Flippy in up to 10 of its 50 restaurants by the end of the year, but it doesn't intend to kick humans to the curb as a result. Flippy will handle the gruntwork, freeing employees to tidy the dining rooms and refill drinks‚Äîless arduous work that might make it easier to recruit and retain workers.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"We're a long way from teaching a robot to walk the restaurant and do those things," said John Miller, CaliBurger's chief executive and founder.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The hospitality industry had 844,000 unfilled positions in April, a record high, according to the @usdol. That accounts for about one out of every eight jobs available in America. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
And while the rise of machines in theory should lead restaurants to employ fewer people per establishment, so far that's not happening. Nationwide, employment is up at individual quick-service restaurants, to 18.4 workers per establishment last year, from 17.4 before the recession began in late 2007.‚†Ä

Thousands of years ago, Bedouin breeders began noting lineages of Arabian mares and stallions, prized for their ability to withstand extreme heat, cold and thirst. Camels were reliable for carrying loads across the desert, but on a raid or in battle, a #Bedouin would trust his life only to an Arabian horse. They ruthlessly selected for stamina, speed, soundness and courage, allowing only the very best horses to breed.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Many places in the Middle East are known as hotbeds for Arabian horses. According to legend, the breed originated from the "south wind," which some have interpreted as meaning they came from #Yemen. Others credit the Bedouin tribes on #SaudiArabia's Nejd plateau as the nucleus of breeders from which the horses arose. #Bahrain, the #UnitedArabEmirates, #Jordan, #Syria and #Egypt can all point to famous stables that have produced refined and prolific Arabian lineages.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
On the southeastern edge of the Arabian Peninsula, #Oman is known for its limestone mountains, blue fiords, limitless deserts and unspoiled beaches. What's lesser known, however, is that it's a surprisingly luxurious destination for travelers. Although horses are ingrained in Omani culture, horse-riding tourism is still developing.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
For Far & Away, a collaboration between @wsj and @natgeo, @petergwin explores the horses that changed history. ‚†Ä

At work as an executive vice president at Sony Pictures, John Naveira's parking spot sits at the bottom of a 94-foot tall rainbow sculpture in Culver City, Calif. The rainbow is a nod to "The Wizard of Oz," which was filmed on what is now the @sonypictures lot in the late 1930s. When the Burbank, Calif., resident parks his 1972 #Datsun 240Z there, everyone can see it‚Äîand the symbolism is obvious. It's like a pot of gold at the end of the rainbow, he says. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
It was 2012 when Mr. Naveira's son came home and told him he saw a 240Z for sale three blocks away. The Z has always been an important car for him, but he had never owned one. When he was in junior high, a neighbor parked her red Z next to his mother's Chevy Impala, and Mr. Naveira fell in love with the car. His wife once owned a 280Z, and both of her brothers have owned 240Zs. "You have to buy that car," his brother-in-law told him. So he did‚Äîfor $2,200.
‚†Ä
Datsun, formerly a division of @nissan in the U.S., created the 240Z in 1969. It was an affordable and reliable mass-produced Japanese sports car to compete against more expensive British sports cars‚Äîa poor man's Jaguar, as Mr. Naveira calls it, with a 2.4-liter engine. The car was so successful that Nissan still builds Zs, but to him, nothing rivals the first generation, model years 1970 to 1973. He often hears Z fans say that 1972 is the best year.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Mr. Naveira's 240Z had a bigger 280ZX engine and a five-speed manual transmission installed at a local restoration shop that Nissan has commissioned to restore old Zs. He keeps the passenger window open when driving, because he always gets a reaction from someone.

‚†Ä

Many also resent a creeping autocracy, as the president has dismantled most of Nicaragua's democratic institutions. ‚†Ä

Bhekindlela Mwelase has lived and worked on contested South African land his entire life. Like other members of the small community about a mile from Hilton College's manicured lawns and gabled schoolhouses, he can't expand the home he shares with more than a dozen members of his family, keep more than three adult goats or even invite visitors without approval from the exclusive boys' boarding school that has educated #SouthAfrica's elite for the past century.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Who the land belongs to‚Äîthe college that bought it in 1860 or the 87-year-old Mr. Mwelase, whose family has lived on it for many generations longer‚Äîis at the center of an intensifying political debate roiling Africa's most developed economy 24 years after the end of white minority rule.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
President Cyril Ramaphosa and the ruling African National Congress have pledged to pass laws letting the government expropriate land without compensation, a high-stakes move they say is necessary to remake some of the deep inequalities plaguing South Africa. White Afrikaner interest groups have threatened to take legal action against the planned expropriations bill and warned that it could drive them out of the country.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Mr. Mwelase says his family should benefit from a 1996 law that promised labor tenants government help to buy the plots they have been living on. Barred from owning property under apartheid rules, black labor tenants‚Äîsimilar to sharecroppers in the U.S.‚Äîswapped work for the right to live, raise crops and graze livestock on white-owned land.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Mr. Mwelase, his health fading, is waiting for a ruling on his land claim, which was first entered in 2001 and is disputed by Hilton College (shown in the second photo).‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"I was born here," Mr. Mwelase said as he sat in his backyard. "I worked there from the first day I remember to the day I retired."‚†Ä

Its sheer size defies gravity. Its grace and elegance defy reason. The @boeing 747, mother of all jumbo jets, is in its twilight years for passenger service, leaving multitudes of travelers nostalgic for a time when air travel was comfortable and exhilarating.‚†Ä

Only 180 of the original jumbo jets, dubbed the Queen of the Skies, remain in passenger service. Boeing built more than 1,500 of the 747s‚Äîpassenger and cargo versions‚Äîbut is unlikely to be building any more of the passenger variety, as the 24 orders that remain are all freighters. @Delta and @United, the last U.S. airlines flying the two-aisle humped giant, both retired their remaining 747s late last year.‚†Ä

On Saturday, United hosted five 747 aficionados who bid frequent-flier miles, along with their guests and some employees, for a final tour and celebration of the airline's last one, tail number N118UA, in Tupelo, Miss. The aircraft is to be stripped of parts and cut up for recycling. ‚†Ä

"I never had a bad flight on it," said Ted Birren, a school administrator from the Chicago area who was one of the 420,000-mile bidders. Like many travelers, he says the physics of the 747 still boggle his mind. ‚†Ä

"To get something that big off the ground is amazing," he added. "This plane really set the pace for the airline industry as we know it today."‚†Ä

Momotaro sells its products at a handful of its own shops in Japan as well as small boutiques New York, Chicago, Seattle and Los Angeles.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Japanese denim has achieved cult status among denim snobs in the U.S., with high-priced pairs selling at the likes of @barneysny and @neimanmarcus. But even @gap notes that it "now consistently offers Japanese selvedge within its denim assortment."‚†Ä
‚†Ä
While early Japanese denim brands from the 1960s and '70s were known for reproducing American denim, today's crop is taking a more artisanal tack, touting the kind of craftsmanship that might go into a piece of Japanese lacquer ware or pottery‚Äîwith a price to match.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"American tradition made better? Many people have said that to us. We're not thinking about making something American," says Tatsushi Tabuchi, general manager of Momotaro (pictured in the third photo).‚†Ä

The battle for hegemony in the Middle East is playing out at the ancient African port or Berbera, where traditional dhow fishing boats now share space with giant container ships loaded around the clock. At stake is the precarious peace in one of the world‚Äôs most volatile and strategic corners, and the balance of power in the Middle East.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Berbera, in the breakaway republic of Somaliland, is perched on a narrow shipping lane leading to the Suez Canal and is just 260 nautical miles from Yemen‚Äôs civil war. Described by colonial-era travelers as the "key to the Red Sea," the port became an Ottoman stronghold and later a British colonial outpost.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
That explains why the U.A.E., Saudi Arabia‚Äôs strongest ally, pledged close to $450 million to take over the port here. Elsewhere along the Horn of Africa, the two allies have snapped up ports and military bases at sites in Somalia, plus farther north in Djibouti and Eritrea. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Qatar and Turkey, which support a different model of political Islam and are closer to Saudi Arabia's arch-rival Iran, are building in Somalia and Sudan. China, meanwhile, is positioned with a military base and a container port in Djibouti and is exploring sites in Somalia, while the U.S. currently conducts Africa operations and directs drones from Camp Lemonnier in Djibouti, the largest U.S. base on the continent.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"We have new kids on the block‚Ä¶competition in the Middle East between the Sunnis and the Shias, and the Americans, the Russians, the Turks, the Qataris," said Saad Ali Shire, Somaliland's foreign minister. "It‚Äôs a poisonous meeting of interests coming together."‚†Ä
‚†Ä

Once upon a time, the NBA wasn‚Äôt cool, but the evolution of the game and the league itself over the last decade has resulted in another golden age for the sport. Now, on the precipice of a fourth straight Finals between the Golden State @Warriors and @Cavs, the teams that have defined this era of the NBA, it‚Äôs worth rewinding to understand how the league‚Äôs radical transformation happened.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
When the @NBA struck a $24 billion media deal in 2014, the league suddenly had a curious sort of problem: It was about to make too much too quickly. When the players‚Äô union rejected a proposal to spread the revenue injection over several years, there was a one-time spike in the salary cap that fundamentally disrupted the league‚Äôs competitive balance. The pool of money allotted to each team ballooned from $70 million to $94 million, or 34%, which amounted to roughly the same growth in one year as the last decade.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
In the summer of 2016, every team was flush with cash. Some teams got greedy and have been squeezed financially ever since. The Warriors got @kevindurant. It would have been impossible for Golden State to sign him and keep its core if Durant had been a free agent at any other time in NBA history.‚†Ä

Forty-two years ago, Jim Weddle moved to Connersville, Ind., with his wife Stacey to open a branch office of the investment company Edward Jones, and discovered an amazing automotive history.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
In the 1920s and '30s, an industrialist named Errett Lobban (E.L.) Cord built Auburn and Duesenberg cars in Indiana. In 1929, he set out to build a car with his own name on it. Cord created a state-of-the-art car factory in Connersville to produce Cord and Auburn cars. Historians have called the small town Indiana's "Little Detroit."‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Cord cars were luxurious and ahead of their time in terms of styling and engineering. Unfortunately, the Great Depression had a devastating effect on Indiana's auto business. Auburn, Duesenberg and Cord all ended production during the Depression. But the people of Indiana still celebrate these cars. The Weddles would see Cords at July 4th parades in Connersville, and Jim remembers saying to his wife years ago, "someday we are going to own one of those cars."‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Ten years ago, Jim and his wife fulfilled their goal when they found the 812 Phaeton pictured above through a classic car broker for $200,000. The car has front-wheel drive, retractable headlights controlled by cranks on either side of the dashboard, and a V-8 engine built by E.L. Cord's Lycoming company. The car had already been restored, and Jim said it is a delight to drive once you figure out its quirks. ‚†Ä

"Everybody‚Äôs got their interpretation of it," adds Tracey Gates, owner of @thebusybeeatl, Atlanta's standard-bearer for traditional fried chicken. "Piri piri fried chicken, how it's done in India, Africa, Korea‚Ä¶they're bringing it back here with their spin on it. I think that's awesome."‚†Ä

Jumia is Africa's aspiring Amazon, or China's Alibaba, and big-name investors like Goldman Sachs have taken note. The online retailer launched in 2012 in Nigeria with the backing of a German startup, and is now the continent's biggest e-commerce platform, selling goods and services to millions of Africans. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Jumia has expanded from four to 14 countries, and raised more than $700 million from investors in the process. It was valued at $1.2 billion during its last fundraising round in 2016. Gross sales last year reached $597 million, up 42% from the year prior. Its vendor network spans from Cape Town, South Africa, to Casablanca, Morocco, and includes up to 70,000 businesses offering their goods and services online.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Jumia's impressive growth story has also outlined the scale of the challenge for African online retail, which is faced with poor internet connections and tight bank lending for vendors and consumers. As a result, Jumia has had to build from scratch much of the economic infrastructure within which it can operate. The company has adapted by accepting cash on delivery from customers, setting up credit lines and offering loans to vetted vendors, and holding training workshops on basic accounting and stock-keeping. ‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"Nowhere else in the world is it more difficult to shop than in Africa," said Sacha Poignonnec, Jumia's co-founder and chief executive.‚†Ä

A painting that had spent more than a century languishing in obscurity will be attributed Wednesday to one of the greatest artists of the Renaissance, #AndreaMantegna (1431-1506). It means the painting, titled "The Resurrection of Christ," a wooden panel depicting Jesus's resurrection, may be worth about a thousand times more than was previously thought: between $25 million and $30 million.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
In March, the curator of the @accademia_carrara in Bergamo, Italy, a city about 30 miles north of Milan, was preparing a catalogue of works dating from before 1500 when he was struck by the excellence of a dark painting on a panel about 19 inches high and 15 inches wide. The work long ago had been removed from the museum's permanent exhibition, dismissed in the 1930s by a prominent art historian as a mere contemporary copy of a lost Mantegna.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Several clues caught the curator's eye, suggesting that the painting had been cut from what was once a larger piece of work by the artist, called "Descent Into Limbo" (seen in the second image). The attribution to Mantegna now has the backing of Keith Christiansen of the @metmuseum in New York City, the world's leading expert on the artist.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"It's a wonderful surprise," said Dr. Christiansen. "An absolutely top-quality work by one of the defining artists of the early Renaissance."‚†Ä

Prices for scrap paper and plastic have collapsed, leading local officials across the U.S. to charge residents more to collect recyclables and send some to landfills. The upended economics are likely to permanently change the U.S. recycling business at places like Cal-Waste Recovery Systems near Sacramento, Calif., pictured above. ‚†Ä

#TomWolfe, the best-selling alchemist of fiction and nonfiction who wrote "The Bonfire of the Vanities," "The Right Stuff" and countless other novels and works of journalism, died of pneumonia in a New York hospital Monday. He was 88 years old.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Mr. Wolfe was a creator of #NewJournalism, a bracing watershed in immersive reporting and visceral writing that removed the authorial distance and plunged readers into subcultures including the psychedelic enthusiasts in his 1968 work, "The Electric Kool-Aid Acid Test." With "The Right Stuff," Mr. Wolfe wrote a generation-defining narrative documenting the early years of America's space program.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
In "The Bonfire of the Vanities," he cast a scorching lens on the mores of New York City‚Äôs philanthropists during the flush years of the 1980s. A number of years later, his novel "A Man in Full" examined race relations and swashbuckling property developers in the South.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"You couldn't compete with him because he's incomparable," said Gay Talese, another pioneer of New Journalism.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
"He created words. There‚Äôs a whole language he started."‚†Ä
