Some 50 miles away, Israeli military used warplanes to hit targets belonging to Gaza rulers Hamas and fired live ammunition, tear gas and rubber bullets at Palestinian protesters near the fence dividing the Gaza Strip with Israel. Gaza officials said 52 protesters were killed‚Äîamong them a 12- and a 14-year-old‚Äîand more than 2,400 were injured. The response from the Israeli military produced the largest single-day death toll since the Israeli army fought a conflict with Hamas in 2014.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
The bloodshed was the culmination of months of tension over President Donald Trump's decision to move the U.S. Embassy to Jerusalem from Tel Aviv, where it has resided since soon after Israel's 1948 founding. It coincided with a host of politically charged anniversaries that Hamas have used to rally support for their cause, at a time when some governments in the region have sought better ties with Israel and scaled back aid to the Palestinians.‚†Ä

In the shadow of a misty mountain range in Tanzania, an elite special-forces unit of African giant pouched rats is training for a dangerous mission: ridding the world‚Äôs formerly war-torn regions of land mines.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Their keen sense of smell allows these rats to sniff out explosives faster, and more reliably, than traditional minesweeping technology. In fact, the rats‚Äô noses are so hypersensitive that they can detect tuberculosis in mucus samples more accurately than local lab tests, and ferret out criminals trying to smuggle endangered species like pangolins.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
According to Apopo, a nonprofit founded in Belgium that breeds and trains the rats, it could take a person with a metal detector up to four days to clear an area the size of a tennis court. In eastern Tanzania, Samia the rat (pictured eating a banana) clears the same ground in 30 minutes, and at 2 to 3 pounds in weight, rats like her are too light to set off a land mine. In 20 years, no rat has been killed in the line of duty, according to Apopo. The one downside: the rats are nocturnal and "weather sensitive," nearly refusing to work in the rain.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
Any day now, Apopo says Samia will be deployed to Angola, where a 27-year civil war that ended in 2002 left swaths of the country covered in mines. Some of her fellow recruits could be heading to Cambodia, Mozambique or Colombia.‚†Ä

In 1968, "the man in black" Johnny Cash made music history when he recorded a live performance for inmates at Folsom State Prison in California. "We don't want people to forget about them," Jorge Hern√°ndez, the group's 64-year-old lead vocalist and accordion player, said of the inmates, before he, his three brothers and a cousin‚Äîall wearing black in tribute to Mr. Cash‚Äîtook the stage on the prison yard. "I feel like I am with them because they are my blood." Los Tigres del Norte, known for its norte√±o folk music, was interested in performing at Folsom in part because of the large increase in Latino incarcerations, the band members said. Latinos total 43% of the 130,000 inmates in the California penal system, up from 34% in 1998, including many who are Mexican immigrants like the band members themselves. They knew who she was, but hadn't yet realized she was a 43-year-old stay-at-home mother living in the suburbs of Tokyo. The NBA contacted Yamano after the story ran and offered to pay for her trip to a potential Thunder playoff game.

Read more about the series of unlikely events that culminated with Yamano sitting courtside at a Thunder playoff game ‚Äî and meeting Oklahoma City forward @flydre21 ‚Äî at the link in our bio. üì∑: @brettdeering  #nba

Don‚Äôt call it a veggie burger. @impossible_foods has imitated the true-blue look, smell, taste and texture of a ground-beef patty in a way that some might find unsettling in the uncanny-valley sense, writes @alisoneroman.

Their secret is an oxygen-carrying compound called heme, which makes blood appear red and makes meat taste... well, meaty. It is heme that gives the burger that I-can‚Äôt-believe-it‚Äôs-not-beef flavor and bloodiness (yes, this patty even bleeds). All this flavor and bleeding comes at a price, which for now is on par with premium ground beef. It is currently being sold in more than 1,000 U.S. restaurants, including national chains and its latest adopter, @whitecastle. The hearty, woodsy version of the Impossible Burger (pictured right) ‚Äîwith mushroom pur√©e, sherry onions and truffle cream‚Äî is on the menu at @saxonandparole in New York City.

Terramino Foods‚Äö the maker of the "salmon" burger (pictured at left), is still testing its imitation of America's favorite fish. Their version is made of fungi protein cultured using koji‚Äîa mold that‚Äôs a key ingredient in soy sauce, miso and other fermented foods‚Äîas well as algae for natural color and flavor. It‚Äôs expected to hit select restaurants and grocery stores in 2019. üì∑: @aringstad for the WSJ

#Iceland‚Äôs Nordic climate and the geothermal steam rising from the tectonic fault line that runs beneath the country provide two things the computers that run the world‚Äôs economy need in seemingly endless supply: cooling and electricity. But the voracious electricity demand of Iceland‚Äôs multiplying data centers is now testing the country‚Äôs environmental values.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
By 2030, data centers and all internet-related activity‚Äîfrom streaming video to analyzing financial data to storing software, photos and emails‚Äîcould use more electricity than all of China did this year. Iceland is riding the boom to satisfy the world‚Äôs newest power-hungry industry, but many of the country‚Äôs lawmakers say they worry this is putting Iceland‚Äôs pristine nature at risk‚Äîthe main draw for millions of tourists that visit the country every year.‚†Ä
‚†Ä
In the first and second images, the Ithe Svartsengi geothermal plant, which is operated by Iceland‚Äôs only private utility, HS Orka. In the third photo, a view of the Verne Global data center. In the final photo, a plume rises from the geothermal well at Eldvorp.

"It put the world on wheels." Tim Kelly, of Schaumburg, Ill., never dreamed of one day having a car collection, but then he ran into a Ford Model T buried in his friend's barn. "I thought, I would love to take something like that and rebuild it back to its old grandeur." The Model T was so affordable and reliable that some 15 million were sold between 1908 and 1927.

Today, Tim and his wife, Carrie, have a personal collection of 13 vehicles, including a 1905 Holsman, a British tank and several Model T's‚Äîincluding a 1917 Runabout and a 1919 model originally used as a taxi, with custom wood bodywork.

It took a year to restore that first Model T barn find, and Tim lost three fingers in the process after one bad error with a table saw. "I look at the bright side: Now I do not have to pretend to enjoy playing golf," he said.

Read more at the link in our bio. üì∑: @jessechehak

Some 400,000 Syrians have died from bullets, bombs, chemical weapons attacks or torture during the country's brutal seven-year war‚Äîbut even more may have died as a result of the breakdown of its health system.

The regime of President Bashar al-Assad has targeted hospitals, clinics and medical personnel in a strategy to destroy the country‚Äôs medical infrastructure. Between the fighting and the destruction done to the health-care system, today most Syrians can‚Äôt expect to live to 65. Chronic conditions such as diabetes and heart disease have become far more deadly, according to reports from the @WorldBank and @who. Many perish because they can‚Äôt get medicine, or even reach a hospital.

In the first photo, a Syrian woman holds her child as he receives a vaccination from a clinic in Raqqa. In the second photo, a destroyed ambulance lies in front of Raqqa's ruined hospital. In the third, a Syrian boy buys medicines from a private pharmacy in Ain Issa, a town north of Raqqa.

Read more about Syria's crippling public-health catastrophe at the link in our bio. üì∑: @ahmd_deeb for The Wall Street Journal

Playa Vista, a newly built neighborhood on the west side of Los Angeles, lacks much of what locals would consider luxury. There are no estates, no sweeping views or movie-star enclaves. Yet houses there are selling for over $4 million, and rents are eye-watering.

That is because Playa Vista, which sits roughly between the oceanside neighborhood of Marina del Rey and Culver City, is in the final stages of a reinvention, providing office space for the biggest names in tech as well as dense, urban-style living for residents. In the fall, Alphabet Inc.‚Äôs Google unit will begin moving employees into a 319,000-square-foot office space, adjacent to 12 acres of land the company purchased in 2014. Yahoo, Microsoft, IMAX, Electronic Arts and YouTube are already there, while Facebook leases a 50,000-square-foot space across the street.

Read more at the link in our bio. üì∑: @michalczerwonka

‚†Ä
Venezuelan President Nicol√°s Maduro‚Äôs regime prohibits most international humanitarian donations‚Äîincluding contributions of lifesaving medicines‚Äîexcept from a few remaining allies such as Russia. Winnie Madikizela-Mandela‚Äîwho like her former spouse, Nelson Mandela, endured prison and personal sacrifices for black freedom, but became a divisive figure in a democratic South Africa‚Äîdied Monday. The second wife of Mr. Mandela, South Africa‚Äôs first black president, she was the public face of the fight against white-minority rule during her husband‚Äôs 27-year political imprisonment. Ms. Madikizela-Mandela won global recognition for her struggle on behalf of the antiapartheid movement, as well as unwanted scrutiny over how she resisted white-minority rule. In this photograph, from July 17, 1988, Ms. Madikizela-Mandela raises her fist in a black power salute after announcing that a massive pop concert would be held to mark the 70th birthday of Mr. Mandela. üí° By all appearances, we‚Äôre in a golden age of innovation. Every month sees new advances in artificial intelligence, gene therapy, robotics and software apps. There are more scientists and engineers in the U.S. than ever before. None of this has translated into meaningful advances in Americans‚Äô standard of living. We explore why in a new series The Innovation Paradox, which you can explore at the link in our bio.
üí° The economy‚Äôs hidden problem: we're out of big ideas. Our new multimedia series explains how this curbs growth and looks at possible solutions. See the whole package at the link in our bio.

üèÜ Stumped for solutions to hundreds of industrial and technical problems, businesses and governments alike are turning the search for innovative ideas into prize-worthy puzzles that capitalize on the ingenuity of the crowd. At a time when the pace of innovation seems to be slowing, prize sponsors hope that today‚Äôs hackers and makers can step into the breach and jump-start progress in a way that today‚Äôs research institutions‚Äîwith their many constituencies and restraints‚Äîare struggling to do. Read more from our special report The Innovation Paradox at the link in our bio.

üá®üá≥ China‚Äôs four great inventions‚Äîpaper, the printing press, gunpowder and the compass‚Äîwere all developed more than a millennium ago. Chinese leaders don‚Äôt want to wait another thousand years for the fifth. Beijing is spending billions on moonshot projects such as teleportation and artificial intelligence, hoping to shake off its reputation as a copycat economy and curb dependence on foreign powers. Read more from our special report The Innovation Paradox at the link in our bio.

üí° How well do you know the history of human innovation? Our interactive timeline explores how inventors have improved upon the work of those before them to push human progress forward. Check it out at the link in our bio.

üíä French drug giant Sanofi is betting that a biotech partnership named after a Star Trek premise will help it crack one of the biggest mysteries in pharmaceutical research: molecules that drive diseases, including some cancers, that have been considered ‚Äúundruggable‚Äù because of their shape. See how in The Innovation Paradox, our special report at the link in our bio.

‚òÅÔ∏è Silicon Valley is finding the physical world is harder than the digital one. Companies like Google parent Alphabet and others have tried to reinvent everything from cars to thermostats to contact lenses. But unlike the digital world, the physical is constrained by physics. Read more from our series The Innovation Paradox at the link in our bio.

üí° In 1879, Thomas Edison developed the first commercially practical light bulb. It's just one of hundreds of innovations on our timeline tracing the iterative progress of human history. Check it out at the link in our bio.

üí°The Innovation Paradox: We interviewed six pioneers in science, medicine and technology about everything from challenging conventional wisdom to taking the long view. See all the clips and check out our entire series on The Innovation Paradox at the link in our bio.

Shimon Peres, the Israeli statesman who earned a Nobel Prize for his tireless efforts to forge peace with Palestinians, died on Tuesday. He was 93.

Over a seven-decade career, Mr. Peres served as prime minister, president and Labor Party chief. He was the last surviving member of a group of leaders who witnessed the creation of the state of Israel in 1948, including David Ben-Gurion, Moshe Dayan, Golda Meir and Ariel Sharon, among others. (üì∑ AFP/Getty)

Tanya Peare works at Century Furniture in Hickory, N.C. The company has 845 workers in the state, down from 1,323 in 2003. In the late 1990s, Hickory seemed sheltered from the disruptive forces of globalization. Laid-off steelworkers from West Virginia, Tennessee and beyond streamed here for new jobs building beds, tables and chairs for American homes. The unemployment rate fell below 2%. These days, Hickory is still suffering from a series of economic shocks, none more powerful than China‚Äôs rise as an export power. The invasion of imported furniture drove factories out of business, erased thousands of jobs and helped drive unemployment above 15% in 2010. üì∑ Mike Belleme for The Wall Street Journal

#regram from @joeparkinson: This is Siphewe, Sibonelo and Tato looking down towards their high school -- Orlando West -- in Soweto. Orlando West used to be a symbol of hope in the township that epitomised the struggle against apartheid. Nelson Mandela, an evangelist for the power of education, lived down the road and left money to the school in his will to fund university scholarships for it's best and brightest. But 22 years after Mandela was elected to president on a promise to lead all South Africans to prosperity, Orlando West is failing and so are its students: roughly half drop out before graduation and drug abuse is rife. Troubles at Orlando West reflect how far South Africa's education system has fallen short of its goal: to be an engine of equality to help correct the crimes of apartheid. 
Read this story, reported with @patmcgroarty with photos by @charlieshoemaker, at the link in our bio. #southafrica

A cultural preference for male children has cost Asia dearly. For decades, South Korea was Exhibit A in this depressing trend. By 1990, as medical advances made prenatal sex selection routine, the ratio of male-to-female babies soared in South Korea to the world‚Äôs highest, at 116.5 males for every 100 females. Then something unusual happened. South Korea did a U turn. In one generation, South Korea has gone from a society where sons are prized to one where daughters are just as eagerly received. 64-year-old Lim Ki-ouk (top right) says she once saw herself as a failure for only having daughters, but now she is envied. See how South Korea reversed course and the challenges other countries will face at the link in our bio. (üì∑: @truth_leem for @WSJ) #southkorea #2050 #demographics

Brides are scarce in the state of Haryana, home to one of India‚Äôs most skewed male-female sex ratios. In 2011, the latest census, the state‚Äôs sex ratio was about 120 boys for every 100 girls. A cultural preference for male children has cost Asia dearly. If you count up all the girls who were never born because of selective abortion, victims of infanticide, and females who died of neglect, in 2050 the world will be missing 142 million women, mostly from China and India. This week on @wsj we're looking ahead - to the year 2050. What will the global economy look like in the next 35 years? Starting next year, the combined working age populations of the world's advanced economies will decline for the first time since 1950, according to UN projections. By 2050, it will shrink 5%, threatening global growth. In a series of multimedia stories, we'll look into the future at these forces, the lives they're affecting, and the race to find solutions. Fereshta's husband joined the Afghan army in the spring of 2013. Three months later, he was killed, leaving Fereshta alone with five children. @wsj reporters @joeparkinson @drew.hinshaw  and photographer @mkcoursin traveled to North Africa to write about a little-known but crucial aspect of the #migrant crisis: many people never make it. @joeparkinson writes: ‚ÄúThis migrant squat in Rabat, Morocco, is called 'The Titanic' because it's large and full of travelers who might not make it. The 50 housemates squeezed into three rooms include multilingual university graduates, former army officers, and even a successful pop singer, who now dine nightly on 50-cent meals of eggs and stale bread. Some have been stuck here for years; robbed and tortured by smugglers, shunned by neighbors and sliced by barbed wire on border fencers they have tried to scale.‚Äù Follow @joeparkinson @drew.hinshaw and @mkcoursin for more. Read the full story at WSJ.com.

Thousands of West Africans, trying to reach Europe, are living in forests in #Morocco like this tent camp. Some-maybe most-of the young men (and two women) living here are college graduates. Many spoke fluent French, English, Hausa, some Arabic. @drew.hinshaw writes: ‚ÄúIt was like a small United Nations, but of people who can't get to Europe. At night, they sing Rihanna songs around a camp fire: ‚ÄòShine Bright Like a Diamond.‚Äô" Follow @WSJ reporters @drew.hinshaw @joeparkinson and photographer @mkcoursin for more photos.

Syrian refugees waiting for cars to skirt them north to Serbia sit in the smuggling house where they've been held for the last few days in Sofia, Bulgaria. In a Mafia-run hostel in the center of #Bulgaria's capital, Afghan #migrants wait to be smuggled west towards Germany. WSJ reporters @joeparkinson and @georgi_kantchev met them there. They write: "This building, inside a sealed compound, was packed with 80 migrants: they share three fetid squat toilets and have hive marks from bedbugs. Locked inside by smuggling gangs until their ride - or the money for their journey - arrives, some have waited here more than a week. Others are too exhausted and traumatized from their journey to continue traveling. Patrolling guards keep everyone inside, as does the manager, a tall blond transvestite (really). We travelled through the Balkans to investigate how organized crime is capitalizing on the migrant crisis." Read the rest of the story and see more photos from @mkcoursin by following the link in the bio. Follow @joeparkinson and @georgi_kantchev for more photos.

China will abandon its one-child policy, 35 years after it was implemented in 1980. All Chinese couples will now be allowed to have two children, Chinese official media said. The move is symbolically significant and amounts to an acknowledgment of the social and demographic problems policy has created. On WSJ.com, we're showing one-child propaganda through the years, including this sign on the outskirts of a village near Dongying, Shandong province, in August 1997. The sign urges people to ‚Äòimprove the quality of the population‚Äô and ‚Äòcontrol the population increase.‚Äô See more at the link in our bio. (üì∑: Greg Baker/Associated Press)

#Asmara, #Eritrea, is one of Africa‚Äôs most isolated and picturesque capitals. One of the city‚Äôs most famous landmarks is the futurist Fiat Tagliero petrol station built in the 1930s. It is emblematic of the modernist and art-deco buildings of the capital, a legacy of Eritrea's erstwhile  colonial masters, the Italians, who left in a hurry in 1941 as the tide turned against Italy in World War II. Asmara, home to about 600,000, has hardly changed since. WSJ‚Äôs @matinastevis is one of a handful of reporters to have visited the Eritrea, a secretive dictatorship, since foreign correspondents were deported in 2008. WSJ reporter @drew.hinshaw rode along with a group of human traffickers transporting immigrants across the Sahara into Libya. He's been telling the story on Instagram - follow him for more photos and check out the link in our profile for his full story. 
Drew writes: "Tourists used to ride trucks out into this part of the Sahara, in the north of Niger, and camp ‚Äì there's even a vast sea of dinosaur fossils lying in the sand out here. But tourists don't come around anymore ‚Äì al Qaeda kidnappers scared them away ‚Äì and the truck you're seeing here is full of migrants bound for Libya. It's about the only group of foreigners you'll still see in these parts. Some 150,000 Africans will cross through this area this year, en route to the Mediterranean ‚Äì it's great money for drivers. By comparison, sightseeing has died. While photographer @mkcoursin was taking this picture, I visited the local tourism board in Niger's city of Agadez. This year, they'd seen just one tourist: An Italian, who they ordered to travel with a military escort. Amazingly, everybody still shows up at the tourism board for work every day: the tourism director, his secretary, a security guard, a janitor, and a historian were all there when I dropped in. They just hang around, it seems. The secretary sits behind a switched-off computer shrouded in a dust cover. The historian drinks tea. 'It was a dream destination,' said Abdou Haruna, the director of tourism for the city. But, he added: 'We've been living through a crisis ‚Äì a crisis of insecurity. All of that has taken a heavy toll on our tourism.'" (üì∑: @mkcoursin)

WSJ reporter Drew Hinshaw @drew.hinshaw and photographer Mackenzie Knowles-Coursin @mkcoursin just returned from Agadez, Niger, a dusty town on the edge of the Sahara that is being flooded with migrants en route to Europe.  Drew will be sharing a behind-the-scenes look at the story on his own handle, @drew.hinshaw over the next few days, so be sure to follow along. "Ten years ago, as a tourist, I stopped by Agadez, a medieval salt caravan outpost hundreds of miles into the Sahara. It was like hopping back in time. Camels lumbered through the city, houses made of mud. At night, most of the light came from candles. People got around on donkeys. It was like a scene from the Old Testament. It certainly wasn't a place plugged into the global economy: There wasn't a single ATM. Officials told me there were only two banks and maybe five places, total, to send money, Western Union-style back then. So you can imagine my surprise when I returned, this month, to see how a gush of migrants passing through here to Europe has enriched the town. There are 14 banks ‚Äì and countless more money sending shops. Mud brick homes are being replaced by rising cement villas, lighted by solar power, not candles. Everywhere there is evidence of migrant money: I didn't see a camel the entire time. The photographer, @mkcoursin, saw two."

Members of the military leave the presidential compound in Bujumbura, Burundi, on May 17. At the center of the conflict there is President Pierre Nkurunziza's bid for a third term. Burundi's constitution limits the president to two terms. The government plans to hold the election on June 26. The main opposition leader doesn‚Äôt go out in public much because of death threats, but nonetheless says he will run in the presidential election, which he has no illusions of winning. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt want Pierre Nkurunziza to pretend that there are no challengers,‚Äù Agathon Rwasa said. Learn more about Burundi's conflict by visiting our profile link. (Photo: @adrianeohanesian for @WSJ)

In Bujumbura, Burundi's capital, protesters and the military continue to confront each other as people shout for President Pierre Nkurunziza to abandon his bid for a third term. They say they won‚Äôt stop blockading roads, burning tires and hurling stones at passing vehicles until the president accepts the constitution‚Äôs two-term limit. ‚ÄúWe don‚Äôt have guns. But we have stones, so we will fight until the last dies,‚Äù one young man said. The government plans to hold the election on June 26. Mr. Nkurunziza's term ends two months later. As political strife divides Burundi and forces many to flee the country, a community of more than 20,000 Burundians has emerged in the hills of Rwanda. Find the full story with more photos at the link in our profile. (Photo: @adrianeohanesian for @WSJ)

In Burundi‚Äôs capital city, Bujumbura, people take to the streets to face off against police and soldiers, shouting for President Pierre Nkurunziza to abandon his bid for a third term. More than 112,000 people have opted to flee the country and are now filling up refugee camps in Rwanda, Tanzania and the Democratic Republic of Congo. Photojournalist @adrianeohanesian has been covering the crisis there for @WSJ. Here, women and children wait in the rain outside of a clinic in the Mahama Refugee Camp in Rwanda. "For me," she writes, "the most striking aspect of the refugee situation in Rwanda was the fact that a community of over 20,000 Burundians appeared in the hills of Rwanda just within the last few weeks. The conditions in the Mahama refugee camp are already cramped, with an additional 5,000 people awaiting transport from the border, and multiple families sharing the floor space of single tents." We'll be posting more of her photos from Burundi and Rwanda throughout the day. The link in our profile takes you to our full story, with reporting from @heidi.vogt and more photos.

In the hands of Islamic State, one of the Middle East's most renowned archaeologic treasures is now in peril. ‚ÄúThe fighting is putting at risk one of the most significant sites in the Middle East, and its civilian population,‚Äù said Irina Bokova, director-general of Unesco, the United Nations‚Äô cultural agency. Blues legend B.B. King died on Thursday in Las Vegas. He was 89. Mr. King recorded his first hit singles in the 1950s, meaning most fans of popular music have known him their entire lives. He believed the blues comprised a world of emotions - joy, heartache, sensuality and tragedy, among them, and he was at ease in conveying every one. Throughout his decades of performing, he traveling all over the globe, to world capitals and to the White House, promoting a form of American music that grew from the Mississippi Delta where he was raised. Read more about Mr. King at the link in our profile. (Photo: Associated Press)

Ingeborg Rapoport, 102, was 25 when she wrote her doctoral thesis on diptheria. On Wednesday, she finally defended it before an academic committee. She originally submitted it to the University of Hamburg in 1938, but it was rejected for "racial reasons" - she was raised Protestant, but her mother was Jewish. Now, on June 9, it appears she will become the oldest person to ever be conferred a doctoral degree. See more of her incredible story at the link in our profile.

Sometimes the best time to take a photograph of light is after the sun has set, when the landscape itself becomes a canvas. Photographer Tobias Hutzler made his series of images, which his likens to ‚Äúlight drawings,‚Äù by setting up long-exposures on his camera after dusk. He then captured the light trails of artificial light sources and let nature manipulate the path. In this image, titled "Movement #2,‚Äù the photographer captured a trail of light in an Arizona desert. ‚ÄúI love the vastness of the landscape, the beauty in the simplicity of space; it is about energy, light and space,‚Äù he said. Sarkis Teke is the last living native Armenian in a Turkish city of Kayseri that was once full of them. ‚ÄúAll my life I‚Äôve fought to stay here, and I‚Äôve paid a heavy price,‚Äù he says. Friday marks the 100th anniversary of the day that Ottoman authorities began rounding up ethnic Armenian intellectuals and community leaders in Istanbul, then known to Christians as Constantinople. By the end of 1915, the splintering empire‚Äôs minority Armenian communities were wiped out. Turkey still disputes any suggestion that Ottoman forces committed genocide in 1915, saying the deaths occurred as part of war in which Turks were also killed by Armenians. But most independent scholars have described it as genocide, however, and more than 20 nations have formally recognized it as such. Learn more by tapping the link in our profile. (Photo: @moniquejaques for @wsj)

In 2010, Japanese photographer Uruma Takezawa embarked on an ambitious journey to explore and document people and places in the world‚Äôs more remote corners‚Äìwhere people live off the land and in harmony with nature. Traveling by bus, train, on foot, by horseback and even by kayak, Mr. Takezawa traversed 103 countries on four continents in 1,021 days to fulfill a curiosity about the world‚Äôs uncharted corners. ‚ÄúWhat inspired me was my interest in unknown worlds,‚Äù Mr. Takezawa said in an interview. ‚ÄúI wanted to discover and explore with my camera diverse communities that live in some of the remotest parts of our planet. It was also a personal journey of self-discovery. By traveling alone and meeting different people I also learned about myself. Through my photographs, the unknown world became the known world to me.‚Äù He who recently won the Nikkei National Geographic Photo Prize and will display the work in his first U.S. exhibition at Foto-Care Gallery in New York from April 21-May 5. See more of his photos at the link in our profile.

After more than 200 girls  were kidnapped from a school in Chibok in Borno State on April 15, 2014, by #BokoHaram, a terrorist group in northern Nigeria, photographer @glennagordon and @WSJ reporter Drew Hinshaw visited Abuja, Nigeria, a city not far from from Chibok.

While there, Ms. Gordon photographed some of the girls‚Äô belongings, including school uniforms, notebooks, and jewelry, for The Wall Street Journal. She continued the project on her own. Her photos, including this one, were awarded 2nd prize in the General News stories category in the 58th Annual World Press Photo contest on Thursday. The Berlin Wall was erected in 1961 to stem the growing flood of East Germans to the west. Pro-democracy rebellion in East Germany finally forced the border open on Nov. 9, 1989. Checkpoint Charlie (pictured) served for decades as a main entry point into East Berlin for diplomats, journalists and others with a visa. To see more then-and-now photos from the Berlin Wall, click the link in our profile. 
Left photo: Everett Collection. Right: @mustafahabdulaziz for @wsj

Astronomers are warily watching the largest active sunspot in 24 years, which is nearly 20 times the surface of the earth. AR 12192, as solar astronomers call it, has so far launched 6 solar flares toward Earth, intermittently disrupting navigation systems and radio communications. To learn more about solar flares, click the link in our profile. Photo: NASA/SDO

Some 160 Iraqi Kurdish soldiers headed to Syria on Tuesday to join the fight against Islamic State in the embattled city of Kobani. In this picture, a convoy drives through Erbil after leaving a base in northern Iraq. To read more, click the link in our profile. Photo: Reuters

Legendary American fashion designer Oscar de la Renta died Monday at 82. He was perhaps the U.S.'s most noted fashion designer, with a career spanning 6 decades. Tethys, one of Saturn's moons, appears speared by the planet's distinctive rings in this image taken by @NASA's Cassini space probe. The sun is in the Halloween spirit early this year. Mount Sinabung spews hot lava and volcanic ash in North Sumatra, Indonesia, on Thursday. WSJ Reporter Brian Spegele (@bspegele) is in Chongqing, China, covering the fall of Bo Xilai, a charismatic politician once headed for top office who was dismissed from his Communist Party positions. The scandal has ignited Beijing's biggest political crisis since a military crackdown on pro-democracy student protesters in Tiananmen Square in 1989, and China's propaganda machine has gone into overdrive. The caption for this photo: ‚ÄúRed songs in Chongqing's People's Square‚Äù #wsj #china #boxilai #chongqing

"India's starvation deaths are about much more than food. Often they are the result of the failure of multiple government institutions that are supposed to provide a safety net to the poor," writes researcher Ashwin Parulkar.  Munni Devi‚Äôs father-in-law, a 55-year old retired rickshaw driver died after food supplies in his household dwindled. Pictured, Munni Devi, left, with son Kanhaiya and mother-in-law Basanti Devi, right. The @WSJ's India Real Time blog is publishing a six-part series this week showcasing the findings of this investigation. To read the fourth installment, visit: http://on.wsj.com/starving_in_india4 . #wsj #starvinginindia#india #starvation PHOTO CREDIT: Ashwin Parulkar.

Tribal communities are worse off than India‚Äôs average on a host of malnutrition indicators. As part of his investigation into starvation deaths in India, researcher Ashwin Parulkar visited Hindiyankalan, a drought-stricken village that has no electricity and is six miles from the nearest paved road. Families in this village rely on making scoops (winnowing baskets used to separate the husk from the grain) to earn a living. He took this picture of a woman making scoops in Hindiyankalan. The @WSJ's India Real Time blog is publishing a six-part series this week showcasing the findings of this investigation. To read the third installment, visit: http://on.wsj.com/starving_in_india3. #wsj #starvinginindia #india #starvation

Tulsi Manjhi, pictured here with his daughter, recalls laying silently next to his wife, Gita Devi, on a khattiya, a cot made of bamboo and coconut fiber after she gave birth to her sixth child. Villagers recall her losing weight rapidly and say they couldn‚Äôt help because they didn‚Äôt have sufficient food either. ‚ÄúI was hungry too but she couldn‚Äôt even get up,‚Äù Mr. Manjhi recalls. ‚ÄúI tried to feed her jinghi (leaves from trees) once.‚Äù She died eight days after giving birth. An activist who advises India‚Äôs Supreme Court on food security issues deemed Gita Devi‚Äôs a starvation death. The Wall Street Journal‚Äôs India Real Time Blog this week is publishing a six-part series on starvation, showcasing the findings of an investigation by the Centre for Equity Studies. To read the second installment, visit: http://on.wsj.com/starving_in_india2. PHOTO CREDIT: Ashwin Parulkar for The Wall Street Journal. The picture was taken in the Banwara village in India in November 2011. #wsj #starvinginindia #india #starvation

Jhagaru Hazra (pictured) is the older brother of the late Padamchand Hazra, who died in Jharkhand‚Äôs Manjhaladhi village in August 2010 after days without food. Starvation is a brutal but little-discussed reality in India. The Wall Street Journal‚Äôs India Real Time this week is publishing a six-part series on starvation, showcasing the findings of an investigation by the Centre for Equity Studies. Based on government estimates, 35.6% of Indian women and 34.2% of Indian men have a body mass index less than 18.5, the internationally acknowledge threshold for a "normal" BMI. To read more, visit: http://on.wsj.com/starving_in_india. PHOTO CREDIT: Ashwin Parulkar for The Wall Street Journal. #wsj #starvinginindia #india #starvation

How do you start your morning? We asked readers to share their photos, tagging them #morningwsj. Here's one from Abdurrahman Antakyali in Ankara, Turkey. Share yours with the tag #morningwsj. See more reader photos online at on.wsj.com/HgD4SI.

How do you start you're morning? We asked readers to share their photos, tagging them #morningwsj. Here's one from John Posch of Houston. He writes: "The Houston National Cemetery is the second largest veterans cemetery in the US, slightly smaller than Arlington. I pass by it every morning on my way to work, and on March 28 noticed that the sunrise was exceptionally beautiful. I turned in and experienced the rare beauty of the pre-dawn mist providing a backdrop for the solemn setting. After some time for prayer and reflection, I took some photos with my iPhone 4s. It was a wonderful way to start the day." You can see more reader photos online at on.wsj.com/HgD4SI.

Sister Valsa John Malamel, a Christian nun, was murdered in the Indian state of Jharkhand in November. The #wsj's India Real Time blog this week  is running a serialized investigation into her death. It is a story of greed, lust, friendship, betrayal, faith, and brutality. This picture shows the village school that Sister Valsa helped build. #wsj #india #sistervalsa #investigation #pachwara
Another photo from the #wsj investigation about the life and death of Sister Valsa, who was murdered in the Indian state of Jharkhand in November. #village #india #pachwara #wsj

Sister Valsa John Malamel, a Christian nun, was murdered in the Indian state of Jharkhand in November. The #wsj's India Real Time blog this week  is running a serialized investigation into her death. It is a story of greed, lust, friendship, betrayal, faith, and brutality. This picture shows the village of Pachwara that sits in the center of Jharkjand's tribal region. A village of 3,000 people, it stretches for miles and is a collection of small compounds and rickety wooden fences.
